name: Frank Shaver Allen
content:
Frank Shaver Allen (1860–1930), usually known as F. S. Allen was a significant Joliet, Illinois-based American architect noted for his Richardsonian Romanesque school designs.
 Frank Shaver Allen was born in 1860 in Galesburg, Illinois to Sheldon W. and Nancy A. (Shaver) Allen.[1] He seems to have received some training in Chicago.[2] By 1880 he was practicing architecture in Streator, Illinois. In 1886 Allen formed a partnership with John H. Coxhead, the firm being Allen & Coxhead.[3] The partnership was dissolved the following year when Coxhead relocated to St. Paul, Minnesota.[4] Following the dissolution of this partnership Allen moved to Joliet, where he did much of his best-known work.
 In 1893 an exhibit of his work in school architecture at the World's Columbian Exposition received an award from the exposition commission, which led to significant expansion of his practice.[5]
 After being commissioned for work in California, he moved to Los Angeles in 1904 with his family, settling in Pasadena.[6] He originally maintained his practice from Pasadena, but moved it to Los Angeles in 1907. 
 Allen was arrested in 1910, authorities alleging kidnapping,[7] but charges were dropped in 1911 due to lack of evidence.[8] In 1915 he retired from practice.[2] He died in California, August 26, 1930.[1]
 Allen was also an Egyptologist.
 Allen was responsible for a number of buildings that have been listed on the United States National Register of Historic Places.

raw:
Frank Shaver AllenF. S. Allen, 1895Born1860Galesburg, IllinoisDiedAugust 26, 1930CaliforniaNationalityUnited StatesOccupationArchitect
 Joliet Township High School, Joliet, 1901.
Frank Shaver Allen (1860–1930), usually known as F. S. Allen was a significant Joliet, Illinois-based American architect noted for his Richardsonian Romanesque school designs.

Contents

1 Early life and career
2 Legacy
3 Architectural works
4 External links
5 References


Early life and career[edit]
Frank Shaver Allen was born in 1860 in Galesburg, Illinois to Sheldon W. and Nancy A. (Shaver) Allen.[1] He seems to have received some training in Chicago.[2] By 1880 he was practicing architecture in Streator, Illinois. In 1886 Allen formed a partnership with John H. Coxhead, the firm being Allen & Coxhead.[3] The partnership was dissolved the following year when Coxhead relocated to St. Paul, Minnesota.[4] Following the dissolution of this partnership Allen moved to Joliet, where he did much of his best-known work.
In 1893 an exhibit of his work in school architecture at the World's Columbian Exposition received an award from the exposition commission, which led to significant expansion of his practice.[5]
After being commissioned for work in California, he moved to Los Angeles in 1904 with his family, settling in Pasadena.[6] He originally maintained his practice from Pasadena, but moved it to Los Angeles in 1907. 
Allen was arrested in 1910, authorities alleging kidnapping,[7] but charges were dropped in 1911 due to lack of evidence.[8] In 1915 he retired from practice.[2] He died in California, August 26, 1930.[1]
Allen was also an Egyptologist.

Legacy[edit]
Allen was responsible for a number of buildings that have been listed on the United States National Register of Historic Places.
